liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senior government ministers are dismissing growing pressure to review the decision to ban extra Qatar Airways flights into Australia. The federal government quashed a request from the airline to allow additional flights per week into Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane. Acting Queensland Labor Premier Steven Miles says additional flights would push prices down — and he would have approved the request if it was up to state governments. But Employment Minister Tony Burke insists there is no need for a review. "The decision [has] been made by Minister (Catherine) King, based on the national interest, that decision, I have got no reason to question that at all," he said. Meanwhile, Nationals senator Bridget McKenzie wants to launch a Senate inquiry into the government's decision. Senator McKenzie says after not getting answers from the transport minister, she will today call for a Senate inquiry on the issue — also accusing the government of being too cosy with Qantas. "In the absence of her answering the questions and coming clean, it's very easy to assume that this government is continuing to run a protection racket for the most complained about company in our country, when you look at the ACCC figures," she said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Government defends Qatar Airways decision amid calls for inquiry

children.content: Senior government ministers are dismissing growing pressure to review the decision to ban extra
Qatar Airways
flights into Australia.
The federal government quashed a request from the airline to allow additional flights per week
into Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane.
Acting Queensland Labor Premier
Steven Miles
says additional flights would push prices down — and he would have approved the request if it was up to state governments.
But
Employment Minister Tony Burke
insists there is no need for a review.
"The decision [has] been made by Minister (Catherine) King, based on the national interest, that decision, I have got no reason to question that at all," he said.
Meanwhile,
Nationals senator Bridget McKenzie
wants to launch a Senate inquiry into the government's decision.
Senator McKenzie says after not getting answers from the transport minister, she will today call for a Senate inquiry on the issue — also accusing the government of being too cosy with Qantas.

"In the absence of her answering the questions and coming clean, it's very easy to assume that this government is continuing to run a protection racket for the most complained about company in our country, when you look at the ACCC figures," she said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New industrial relations legislation will be introduced to parliament today, which the government says will close loopholes that currently lead to unfair pay and conditions. Political reporter Evelyn Manfield explains what's being debated: This is the second tranche of the government's industrial relations reform. Under the change, the Fair Work Act would be amended to close a so-called loophole where an employer and employees have agreed through an enterprise agreement to a particular rate of pay, but then that pay is undercut when the employer brings in different workers through labour hire. The bill is also promising to introduce greater protections for gig economy workers and casuals, and increase penalties for wage theft. But business groups are opposing the changes, arguing they add complexity and will drive up costs. Political reporter Stephanie Borys was on News Breakfast earlier and said the bill will be debated for four weeks in the House of Representatives before it goes to the Senate where the government needs to find the numbers from the Greens and crossbench to get it through.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New industrial relations legislation to be introduced to parliament

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More wet weather is forecast in Nevada, where thousands of Burning Man festival attendees are being asked to shelter in place. North America correspondent Barbara Miller filed this report a little earlier. Further rain, some thunderstorms and gusty winds are forecast for Black Rock City - the site of the annual Burning Man festival. Tens of thousands of festival-goers are being asked not to leave because the roads are still too wet and muddy to officially open. Local authorities are investigating a death which occurred during the heavy rain. No further details have been provided. After postponing the burning of the huge wooden effigy called the Man, the event's signature event, organisers say they hope to go ahead with it later today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Authorities investigating death at Burning Man

props.alt: People walk through the mud at Burning Man.

children.content: ( Trevor Hughes/USA Today Network via Reuters)
More wet weather is forecast in Nevada, where thousands of Burning Man festival attendees are being asked to shelter in place.
North America correspondent Barbara Miller filed this report a little earlier.
Further rain, some thunderstorms and gusty winds are forecast for Black Rock City - the site of the annual Burning Man festival.
Tens of thousands of festival-goers are being asked not to leave because the roads are still too wet and muddy to officially open.
Local authorities are investigating a death which occurred during the heavy rain. No further details have been provided.
After postponing the burning of the huge wooden effigy called the Man, the event's signature event, organisers say they hope to go ahead with it later today.

title.children: ASX higher, Liontown soars on Albemarle offer, NZ casino Skycity faces suspension

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Household spending was 0.7 per cent lower when compared to July last year, according to figures released today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). Robert Ewing, ABS head of business statistics, said households have curbed their spending over the past 12 months amid higher interest rates and inflation. “This is the first time since February 2021 that the spending indicator has fallen. “Spending on discretionary goods and services was down for the fourth straight month. It fell 3.3 per cent over the year, as households adapt to cost of living pressures. “Non-discretionary spending rose 1.7 per cent, which is the lowest growth rate since early 2021.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Household spending falls for the first time since 2021

children.content: Household spending was 0.7 per cent lower when compared to July last year, according to figures released today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).
Robert Ewing, ABS head of business statistics, said households have curbed their spending over the past 12 months amid higher interest rates and inflation.
“This is the first time since February 2021 that the spending indicator has fallen.
“Spending on discretionary goods and services was down for the fourth straight month. It fell 3.3 per cent over the year, as households adapt to cost of living pressures.
“Non-discretionary spending rose 1.7 per cent, which is the lowest growth rate since early 2021.”

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Liontown Resources shares shot nearly 10 per cent higher after its board backed a refreshed $6.6 billion bid from Albemarle, the world's biggest lithium producer. The new cash offer price of $3 per share represents a premium of 14.5 per cent to Liontown's last closing price of $2.62 on September 1 and is 20 per cent higher than Albemarle's $2.50 per share offer made in late March that the target had rejected as too low. Liontown said its board intended to unanimously recommend a vote in favour of the new takeover proposal, adding that an independent expert concluded that it was in the best interests of shareholders. The news prompted Liontown shares to shoot up 9.4 per cent higher by 11:15am AEST to $2.87, the highest since mid July. Albemarle has been granted a limited period of exclusive due diligence as well as to enter into a mutually acceptable scheme implementation deed, Liontown said in statement.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Liontown backs $6.6b Albemarle bid

children.content: Liontown Resources shares shot nearly 10 per cent higher after its board backed a refreshed $6.6 billion bid from Albemarle,
the world's biggest lithium producer.
The
new cash offer price of $3 per share
represents a premium of 14.5 per cent to Liontown's last closing price of $2.62 on September 1 and is
20 per cent higher than Albemarle's $2.50 per share offer made in late March
that the target had rejected as too low.
Liontown said its board intended to unanimously recommend a vote in favour of the new takeover proposal, adding that an independent expert concluded that it was in the best interests of shareholders.
The news prompted Liontown shares to shoot up 9.4 per cent higher by 11:15am AEST to $2.87, the highest since mid July.
Albemarle has been granted a limited period of exclusive due diligence as well as to enter into a mutually acceptable scheme implementation deed, Liontown said in statement.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New Zealand's SkyCity Entertainment Group on Monday said it was informed by the country's Department of Internal Affairs (DIA) that an application had been made to temporarily suspend the casino license of its SkyCity Casino Management (SCML) unit. The application was made to the country's gambling commission to suspend the unit's casino operator's license for a period "in the range of 10 days", following a complaint made early last year by a former customer who gambled at the SkyCity Auckland casino from August 2017 to February 2021, SkyCity said. "The Secretary (of the DIA) states in the application that SCML did not comply with requirements in its SkyCity Auckland Host Responsibility Programme relating to detection of incidences of continuous play by the customer," SkyCity said in a statement. SkyCity Casino Management is the holder of the company's casino operator's license for its casinos in the Auckland, Hamilton and Queenstown regions in New Zealand. The company did not comment further, adding that it would fully comply with the DIA secretary in relation to the application and process. Last year, Australia's financial crime regulator launched civil proceedings against the operator's casino in Adelaide to crack down on the gambling industry. By 11:08am AEST, its shares were down 14.6 per cent to $1.99.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Casino firm Skycity plunges 15pc

children.content: New Zealand's SkyCity Entertainment Group on Monday said it was informed by the country's Department of Internal Affairs (DIA) that an application had been made to temporarily suspend the casino license of its SkyCity Casino Management (SCML) unit.
The application was made to the country's gambling commission to
suspend the unit's casino operator's license for a period "in the range of 10 days"
, following a complaint made early last year by a former customer who gambled at the SkyCity Auckland casino from August 2017 to February 2021, SkyCity said.

"The Secretary (of the DIA) states in the application that SCML did not comply with requirements in its SkyCity Auckland Host Responsibility Programme relating to detection of incidences of continuous play by the customer," SkyCity said in a statement.
SkyCity Casino Management is the holder of the company's
casino operator's license for its casinos in the Auckland, Hamilton and Queenstown regions
in New Zealand.
The company did not comment further, adding that it would fully comply with the DIA secretary in relation to the application and process.
Last year, Australia's financial crime regulator launched civil proceedings against the operator's casino in Adelaide to crack down on the gambling industry.
By 11:08am AEST, its shares were down 14.6 per cent to $1.99.
